{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3604511,"name":"","username":"yotam201410","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T13:59:00.630Z","cooked":"

Hi, I’m Yotam, I’m a mentor for FRC Team 4416 Skynet, and I want to share a cool solution to wiring CANbus we explored this year: using Ethernet cables and custom PCBs to create a parallel CAN bus network.

Disclaimer

I’m not an electrical engineer, and we don’t have one on the team. I led our electrical subteam during the 2022 season, but my experience outside of FRC and some physics classes is pretty limited. This is all the result of learning by doing.

Why Did We Do This?

Electrical issues—especially CAN signal problems—have plagued us over recent seasons. The 2024 season was the worst offender.

So when the season ended, we sat down to analyze what went wrong. We unanimously agreed: electrical reliability was our biggest weakness.

What We Were Using Before

In 2024, our CAN bus was routed with a mix of connectors:

  • 3-pin Dupont
  • CTRE CAN Connector

We found the CTRE connectors unreliable (frequent disconnects, even with ferrules), and Dupont connectors were difficult to source here in Israel.

Exploring Solutions

We brainstormed several possible improvements:

  1. Solder everything — great performance, but horrible for maintenance.
  2. Use better connectors — Powerpole, Molex SL, etc.
  3. Switch to a parallel CAN bus
  4. Use a different interface entirely
  5. Get good at electronics

Prototyping Time

We prototyped the most promising options:

1. Parallel CAN

We knew some teams had done it. So we tried it out—and successfully retrofitted our 2024 robot with parallel CAN wiring.

2. Ethernet Connectors

We thought: “Why not use Ethernet cables?” They’re easy to plug/unplug, stay secure, and already use twisted pairs. We cut open a cable, wired it up, and tested CAN signal integrity—and it worked great.

The Chosen Solution

Given our timeline (~6 months) and past headaches, we chose to combine both ideas:
Ethernet cables as CAN connectors
Parallel CAN topology

We designed:

  • A “Node” PCB that connects CAN to up to 4 devices and transmits via 4 twisted pairs in a Cat5e Ethernet cable
  • A “Hub” PCB that connects multiple subsystems in parallel and acts as a single CAN chain device

Legality Check

We were initially unsure if Ethernet cables were legal for transmitting CAN signals.

The 2024 manual didn’t prohibit it, and we stayed within the spec. In 2025, Team Update #8 made us nervous, but after discussing with others, we all agreed it was allowed.

That said—inspectors definitely noticed. (Shout out to all the inspectors; we appreciate you. But yeah, it was a little stressful.)

Implementation

Node PCB

image941×639 40 KB

image1920×1440 251 KB

Each subsystem uses a Node PCB. You can wire all motors in parallel or choose to daisy-chain a few and insulate the rest.

For example, if you want one motor disconnecting to break the whole subsystem (for safety or logic), only connect the first motor. If you want all motors to survive one failure, connect each in parallel.

Hub PCB

image201×860 14.3 KB

image1920×2560 330 KB

The hub ties all Node PCBs together. It includes 4 Ethernet ports (1 per subsystem) and two pairs to connect the RIO, PDH, and other CAN devices (like the Pigeon IMU).

Robot Wiring

  • Our swerve modules were wired so each module parallel to the rest of the modules so that if a motor disconnectes to module disconnects so the steer or drive wont kill the wheels, while the rest of the swerve will still work (would need to correct its rotational movement drasticly using PID but would work).
  • For other subsystems (e.g., elevator, intake), motors were wired in full parallel to avoid single-point failures.
  • Usually, people recommend keeping CAN stub lengths under 12", but we ran some stubs over 1.5 meters and had no issues — using shielded cables probably helped.

We decided on our swerve to connect each module parallel to the rest of the modules so that if a motor disconnectes to module disconnects so the steer or drive wont kill the wheels, while the rest of the swerve will still work (would need to correct its rotational movement drasticly using PID but would work).

Performance & Issues

Goal: no CAN-related failures at events
Reality: zero CAN issues at all three of our 2025 competitions (ISR #1, ISR #3, ISR DCMP)

CAN utilization was ~50–60% with 21 devices (14 motors, 4 CANcoders, 1 Pigeon, 1 PDH, 1 RIO).
Not sure if parallel wiring helped or it was just good architecture, but we were very happy with it.

Minor Issues:

  • Ethernet cables aren’t flexible
    Our robot was only 52x52 cm, and routing cables in tight spots was a challenge.

Team 4416 - The Blue Alliance","clicks":15},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/what-are-the-best-practices-for-a-reliable-can-bus-setup/504550/3","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"What Are the Best Practices for a Reliable CAN Bus Setup?","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":24}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51413,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season/500586/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":23},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":24,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3604527,"name":"Michael Hill","username":"Michael_Hill","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/michael_hill/{size}/1110_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T14:15:12.785Z","cooked":"

I’ve always thought CAN over ethernet made sense to do. Understandably, the size of the socket is a major turn-off. Cool solution. As far as flexible ethernet cables go, you can get pretty flexible ethernet cables. Monoprice sells patch cables in pretty small awg that might work for this application, though I’m not sure of the availability in Israel.

yotam201410:

Minor Issues

Did you check the weight of all of those cables? I’m guessing it was substantially more than small green/yellow wires. However, if the reliability increased, it may be worth it.

Our robot weighed roughly 40 kg (88 lbs), so the weight of the cables wasn’t an issue for us. In fact, we are usually well under the weight limit each year, so we weren’t particularly concerned about it.

Sounds interesting!
How does your solution compare to something like a WAGO?
We had the same experience with CTRE connectors in 2023, and this year and 2024 we used WAGO and had zero issues

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-04-26T14:29:30.536Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":620,"readers_count":619,"score":124.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500586,"topic_slug":"how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":59306,"username":"Tom_Neu","name":"Tom","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_neu/{size}/222407_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51413,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season/500586/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3604543,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T14:40:00.753Z","cooked":"

The compliment sandwich :

The bread: I’m glad you had success and reliability with your can network this year!

The meat: The Ethernet cable as a media is fine in my book. I’m a bit more concerned about your network topology though.

Because we are dealing with relatively small CAN 2.0 networks this particular wiring, this year, happened to work for you.

As I understand you: both PDH and Rio with terminating resistors were connected to the hubs and all other devices at various stub lengths to different nodes tied back to the hub.

CAN relies on the placement of the terminations to work reliably (absorbed reflections and improve signal quality). High speed transitions (the signal) cause signal reflections when they reach the END of a stub. A general rule those reflections get worse the longer the stub. Reflections interact constructively and destructively with the original signal and will degrade signal quality (when viewed on an oscilloscope probing different physical length points from a termination), until the signal is unreadable by a device transceiver.

The issue in your topology is that your bus is very short with both terminations at a single or linked hub, and your devices are far away on long stubs. Both of these are bad topology layout decisions.

Because we are using lower speed CAN &&& are relatively small (not the size of a car or tractor), the reflections and degradation of the physical signal were not enough that any of your devices found the signal unreadable.

But because of the topological choice that won’t necessarily be true every year, and you won’t be able to predict when or why it fails…you may add a subsystem and suddenly the whole bus is unusable but you have no mistakes in wiring quality - it’s because the particular stubs and lengths you added, added reflections onto the CAN bus that degraded the signal quality.

You will also run into trouble the faster the CAN network operates, CAN FD most certainly will throw errors if wired this way - and the new 2027 control system may also have trouble - because you are not following the standards we are unable to tell until you try it…every project every year will be a gamble.

Now the other slice of bread: your focus on the CAN network likely lead to more reliable quality wiring and connection points resulting in your year-over-year improvement and meeting your goal of no can issues (not this particular network topology though).

You can redesign your network to still use the techniques and materials (Ethernet cables), that made the difference in your build quality and performance this year and get a more predictable and in-spec result year after year on your CAN bus, but it’s going to remove some of what you found as “pros” in the hub and spoke style topology, being able to “choose” to daisy chain some as a logical or “safety” fault behavior, etc …

In general the bus should look, electrically physically wired, like this:

174567826250660879341802276520981132×492 14.8 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-04-26T14:43:12.670Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":624,"readers_count":623,"score":519.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500586,"topic_slug":"how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":18}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season/500586/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":15},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":18,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3604560,"name":"TomerBARZ","username":"TomerBARZ","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T15:05:09.020Z","cooked":"

Thank you for your in-depth comment! We are aware of the potential issues that our CAN system can cause, and we’ll keep those in mind when preparing for the next season.

Before we committed to this design, we conducted tests on a practice bot using hand-soldered (no PCB connectors) longer wires (over 3m), albeit with fewer CAN devices, to ensure everything would work as expected.

As you mentioned, it probably won’t work on a CANivore’s CAN-FD or on the new SystemCore. In those cases, we’re less concerned about the parallel CAN bus since we can split different subsystems into separate CAN networks (if I understand correctly).

We’ll need to conduct some more testing in preparation for next year, focusing on more CAN devices and varying stub lengths to see if we can stay within spec or if everything breaks completely.

Attached below is the wiring diagram for this year’s robot (red crosses are isolated wires - not terminated with a resistor):

4416 2025 Wiring Diagram1024×1024 228 KB

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-04-26T15:05:09.020Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":559,"readers_count":558,"score":151.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500586,"topic_slug":"how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season","display_username":"TomerBARZ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63541,"username":"Jwal","name":"Joseph Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66893,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAD Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season/500586/8","custom_user_title":"CAD Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"call_me_hand","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605236,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T21:54:21.864Z","cooked":"

I’m not sure if you are following the concepts I spewed out in the early morning for me.

TomerBARZ:

Before we committed to this design, we conducted tests on a practice bot using hand-soldered (no PCB connectors) longer wires (over 3m), albeit with fewer CAN devices, to ensure everything would work as expected.

This is a check of build quality and not of CAN Bus topology/physical layout. If you re-read my message I explain WHY the topology you have chosen cannot be simply “tested” to make sure it will work and give repeatable results. EVERY bus you build like this will be unique - and behavior will be inconsistent the longer and more nodes you add - perhaps failing SUDDENLY and unpredictably.

It may even work the first time you build it, then you have an elevator failure or something where a bunch of devices fall off the BUS, but instead of just those nodes going down because of the change in constructive and destructive interference generated by the reflections on the remaining nodes the ENTIRE bus may become unusable - not just the nodes that became disconnected. Thus your thinking this wiring scheme is more redundant/failure resilient proves to not be any better than the standard at all…

How are you quantifying “staying within spec”? What measurements are you taking to examine signal quality? I fear you may just be taking a resistance reading of the bus looking for ~60Ω, and checking can bus utilization - both of these will reveal not much at all about signal integrity.

Now I AM a fan of the RJ-45 jacks and use of ethernet cable for the CAN bus. I want to sink time into making a standard cable for this, and sensors, to make robot wiring simpler -but its time to invest that I don’t have right now. I think your focus on build QUALITY resulted in your improvement this year but want to be clear for others that the topology (physical and electrical wiring layout), you’ve chosen may be problematic in ways you cannot predict year after year no matter how much testing ahead of time you do. And troubleshooting would require an oscilloscope w/CAN decrypting capabilities (not likely to be found at a competition), and deep Electrical Engineering knowledge.

If your team reads up a bit more on CAN and lays out the BUS more like the standard I think you will see similar success as you did this year with a much more reliable and repeatable implementation!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T21:54:21.864Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":434,"readers_count":433,"score":176.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500586,"topic_slug":"how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-parallel-can-bus-saved-our-2025-season/500586/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605688,"name":"","username":"ninjadrknss","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninjadrknss/{size}/247388_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T03:34:50.835Z","cooked":"
Jwal:

I want to sink time into making a standard cable for this, and sensors, to make robot wiring simpler -but its time to invest that I don’t have right now

I believe SwyftRobot has already created a system for Ethernet-connected CAN if you are willing to pay the headache away.

SWYFT Robotics

SWYFT CANnect Wiring System

Simplify Your Robot Wiring with the SWYFT CANnect Wiring System! Tired of complex robot wiring? SWYFT CANnect revolutionizes your setup by allowing you to run CAN bus and 12V Power over standard Ethernet cables. This drastically reduces wiring...

Price: USD 39.99

Swyft Robotics New Products for 2024/2025 General Forum
NEW PRODUCT ALERT! Tired of complex robot wiring? SWYFT CANnect revolutionizes your setup by allowing you to run both CAN wires from your motors and encoders along with 12V Power over standard Ethernet cables. This drastically reduces wiring complexity, especially for Swerve drivetrains, making your robot cleaner and more reliable. Plus, with built-in redundancy, you can run dual CAN wires to your motors and encoders, ensuring uninterrupted operation even if a wire pair is completely cut! [sw…
Swyft Robotics New Products for 2024/2025 General Forum
Yes, it can carry two independent CAN buses! Here is the ethernet pinout, it is compatible with passive POE yes. [image] Currently: The “loop” bus is used to connect the two buses at the last Direct module so it can be terminated at the Inject.

Tangent:

I knew this existed And this is the bus topology I would recommend to the OP - long bus, termination on each end, short stubs.

I’m still sympathetic to OP’s configuration however as I can see a way to make it work for SENSORS (analog or digital) direct back to the RIO/future control system. That’s where I would need to spend more time…and one of the things I learned in my College days quickly was that there is way more that I need to do/want to do than time I have to do it - so make a prioritized list and start working down it! This falls a few dozen down my current life list

Clean wiring concept! Could be a cool off-season project to test out the short-stub topology on your bot with the same wiring but slight layout modifications to your boards:

image(1)860×201 12.4 KB

image(2)941×639 47.1 KB

Excuse my MS paint ECAD.

You’d need to jumper the hub if you don’t use all 4 RJ45s, but otherwise should be a drop-in replacement.
